Situation A. Changing Percents

What if we wanted to create an image whose side lengths were twice the length of the original? What percent setting should we choose on the copier?

To increase a figure’s size by twice the length, you would want to make each side length 2 times as long as the side length of the original. The percent setting of 200% on the copier would make the side length of image 2 times longer than in the original.

Situation B. Adriana’s Claim

Adriana's Claim

We used rubber band stretchers and photographs to create similar figures. The copier is another way to create similar images.

Do you agree? Explain why or why not.

Agree. The copier creates a more accurate image, but the relationships stay the same. When you want to create an image two times bigger than the original, you would use two rubber bands. You can also use the copier with a 200% percent setting. If you want to make an image three times bigger than the original, you would use three rubber bands. It is the same as when you use the copier with a 300% percent setting. You can use both the rubber bands and the copier when you want to make a similar image.
